$\textbf{Welcome!}$

The purpose of this site is to give an introduction to toric varieties -- and to develop geometric intuition through an interactive 2D-polytope interface.

[[ex-poly-1|Click here]] to load a polytope, and click the lattice points to modify the given polytope.

$\textbf{Intro to polytopes}$

A $\textit{polytope}$, $\Pi \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ is the convex hull of finitely many points.

Equivalently, a polytope is the intersection of finitely many half planes.

We restrict our attention to the convex hulls of lattice points $$\Lambda \subset \RR^2$$also known as $\textit{lattice polytopes}$. Equivalently, lattice polytopes are intersections of half-planes by forms in the dual lattice:$$\Lambda^\vee \subset {(\mathbb{R}^2)}^\vee.$$

To a polytope $\Pi\subset \mathbb{R}^n$ we associate a partially ordered set of $\textit{strata}$: $$\Sigma(\Pi) \subset \mathcal{P}(\Pi).$$Visibly, a stratum is either $\Pi$ or a polytope on the boundary of $\Pi$ (in our example, a vertex, edge or face). (Technically a stratum is a polytope which is the convex hull of a subset of extremal vertices.) The example in the lattice has

$\textbf{The ring associated to a vertex}$

{{vertices[0]|"The cone around any vertex"|select}} $v\in \Pi$ defines a sub-monoid of the lattice $$M_v\subset \Lambda$$defined by vectors between $v$ and any lattice vector in the cone - i.e. by translating the cone so the cone point is moved to the origin $0\in \Lambda$.

Working over a field $k$ we associate to any monoid $M$ the $\textit{monoid ring}$ associated to $M$: $$k[M] = \left\{\sum a_i \chi^{m_i} \middle| m_i \in M, a_i \in k\right\}$$where elements are polynomials in $\chi^m$ for an element $m \in M$ and multiplication is defined by associativity and exponentiation rules.

Now to each vertex we have an associated ring $k[M_v]$. Taking the spectrum gives an affine variety$$X_v = \mathrm{Spec}(k[M_v]).$$

$\textbf{The toric structure}$

There is a natural inclusion $$k[M_v]\subset k[\Lambda]\cong k[x_1^{\pm 1},\cdots,x_n^{\pm 1}].$$The latter is the coordinate ring of the torus $\GG_m^n$ which corresponds to an open inclusion $\GG_m^n \cong \TT \subset X_v$.

$\mathbf{Exercise.}$ Show that $\TT$ naturally acts on $X_v$ and this action respects the inclusion $\TT \subset \GG_m^n$.

Importantly, any $\textit{monomial}$ ($\chi^m$ for $m\in M_v$) spans the unique 1-dimensional sub-representation $$k\cdot \chi^m \subset k[M_v]$$with weight $-m$.
